text: I'm working on some Pluto notebooks to serve as tutorials for students (of all ages!) to learn about some of the data products our team produces and some related domain specific concepts.  Is there a way to host notebooks such that users can access them, interact with the UI elements (sliders, select boxes, etc), see plots and other outputs update dynamically in response to their UI choices, and even look at the contents of the cells to see how they work, but NOT let them edit the contents of the cells (or only edit some cells)?  Is this type of thing being done in classroom settings already?

elements.text: I'm working on some Pluto notebooks to serve as tutorials for students (of all ages!) to learn about some of the data products our team produces and some related domain specific concepts.  Is there a way to host notebooks such that users can access them, interact with the UI elements (sliders, select boxes, etc), see plots and other outputs update dynamically in response to their UI choices, and even look at the contents of the cells to see how they work, but NOT let them edit the contents of the cells (or only edit some cells)?  Is this type of thing being done in classroom settings already?

text:
Have you seen the notebooks for the MIT intro to computational thinking class?
<https://computationalthinking.mit.edu/Spring21/transforming_images/>

elements.text: Have you seen the notebooks for the MIT intro to computational thinking class?

text: That's exactly the kind of thing I'd like to setup!  Where can I find instructions to replicate that setup with my own notebooks?

elements.text: That's exactly the kind of thing I'd like to setup!  Where can I find instructions to replicate that setup with my own notebooks?

text:
I would take a look at the github repo for the website: <https://github.com/mitmath/18S191>

But I personally wasn't involved in this, so when Fons or someone else wakes up, they should be able to give more details on how they set up their containerized environment.

text: Hey! Currently it requires some technical know-how to set this up for your website, but we are working on simplifying the process over the next couple of months!

elements.text: Hey! Currently it requires some technical know-how to set this up for your website, but we are working on simplifying the process over the next couple of months!

text: Looking forward to it!  If you want a beta (or alpha?) tester, I'd be happy to be a :guineapig: for you.

text: Fons also just announced PlutoCon 2021 if you haven't seen it yet. As part of the conference, they will have an online demo page where they host will notebooks online

elements.text: Fons also just announced PlutoCon 2021 if you haven't seen it yet. As part of the conference, they will have an online demo page where they host will notebooks online

text:
"Online demo page
During the conference, we will host an *ONLINE DEMO PAGE* running all your submitted notebooks, for everyone to see! Just like the website <https://computationalthinking.mit.edu/>, we will use our fancy new technology to run sliders, button, webcam inputs, etc. directly on the website.
*Would you like _your cool notebook_ to become an interactive web page?* <https://github.com/JuliaPluto/PlutoCon2021-demos|Submit your notebook> to our website! Be sure to write your name and an introduction inside the notebook. Use `@bind` to make your notebook interactive!"

PlutoCon sounds great!
